column6: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.

column5: Self-monitoring of blood glucose1.6.12 Take the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive into account when offering self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.13 Do not routinely offer self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes unless: the person is on insulin or there is evidence of hypoglycaemic episodes or the person is on oral medication that may increase their risk of hypoglycaemia while driving or operating machinery or.

column5: When depression is accompanied by symptoms of anxiety, the first priority should usually be to treat the depression.
column6: When the person has an anxiety disorder and comorbid depression or depressive symptoms, consult the NICE guideline for the relevant anxiety disorder (see find guidance) and consider treating the anxiety disorder first (since effective treatment of the anxiety disorder will often improve the depression or the depressive symptoms).

column9: For people with moderate or severe depression, provide a combination of antidepressant medication and a high-intensity psychological intervention (CBT or IPT).

column5: Be aware that, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, repaglinide is both clinicallyeffective and cost effective in adults with type 2 diabetes.
column6: However, discuss with any person forwhom repaglinide is being considered, that there is no licensed non-metformin-based combination containing repaglinide that can be offered at first intensification..
column7: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column8: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column9: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column10: For more information, seethe NICE guideline on diabetes in pregnancy. 1.6.14 Consider short-term self-monitoring of blood glucose levels in adults with type 2 diabetes (and review treatment as necessary): when starting treatment with oral or intravenous corticosteroids or to confirm suspected hypoglycaemia. 1.6.15 Be aware that adults with type 2 diabetes who have acute intercurrent illness are at risk of worsening hyperglycaemia.
column11: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column12: Page 21of 44 1.6.22 In adults with type 2 diabetes, review the dose of metformin if the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is below 45 ml minute 1.73m2:.
column13: Stop metformin if the eGFR is below 30 ml minute 1.73m2..
column14: Prescribe metformin with caution for those at risk of a sudden deterioration in kidneyfunction and those at risk of eGFR falling below 45 ml minute 1.73m2. 1.6.23 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, consider initial drug treatment with: a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor or pioglitazone or a sulfonylurea. 1.6.24 In adults with type 2 diabetes, do not offer or continue pioglitazone if they have any of the following: heart failure or history of heart failure.
column15: Treatment with sodium–glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors , may be appropriate forsome adults with type 2 diabetes if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated (see NICE's guidance on canagliflozin, dapagliflozin and empagliflozin as monotherapies for treating type 2 diabetes)..
column16: First intensification of drug treatment1.6.25 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if initial drug treatment with metformin has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: metformin and a DPP-4 inhibitor or metformin and pioglitazone or metformin and a sulfonylurea. 1.6.26 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated and initial drug treatment has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: a DPP-4 inhibitor and pioglitazone or a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea..
column17: Second intensification of drug treatment1.6.27 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if dual therapy with metformin and another oral drug (see recommendation 1.6.25) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider either: triple therapy with: metformin, a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or metformin, pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea or starting insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34). 1.6.28 If triple therapy with metformin and 2 other oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.27) is not effective, not tolerated or contraindicated, consider combination therapy with metformin, a sulfonylurea and a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) mimetic for adults with type 2 diabetes who: have a BMI of 35 kg m2 or higher (adjust accordingly for people from black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups) and specific psychological or other medical problems associated with obesity or have a BMI lower than 35 kg m2and: for whom insulin therapy would have significant occupational implications or weight loss would benefit other significant obesity-related comorbidities. 1.6.29 Only continue GLP-1 mimetic therapy if the person with type 2 diabetes has had a beneficial metabolic response (a reduction of at least 11 mmol mol 1.0percent in.
column18: HbA1c and a weight loss of at least 3percent of initial body weight in 6 months).1.6.30 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, and if dual therapy with 2 oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.26) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34)..
column19: DVLA guidance (At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive)management of hypoglycaemia management of acute changes in plasma glucose control support from an appropriately trained and experienced healthcare professional. 1.6.33 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, continue to offer metformin for people without contraindications or intolerance.
column20: Be aware that, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, repaglinide is both clinicallyeffective and cost effective in adults with type 2 diabetes.
column21: However, discuss with any person forwhom repaglinide is being considered, that there is no licensed non-metformin-based combination containing repaglinide that can be offered at first intensification..
column22: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column23: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column24: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column25: For more information, seethe NICE guideline on diabetes in pregnancy. 1.6.14 Consider short-term self-monitoring of blood glucose levels in adults with type 2 diabetes (and review treatment as necessary): when starting treatment with oral or intravenous corticosteroids or to confirm suspected hypoglycaemia. 1.6.15 Be aware that adults with type 2 diabetes who have acute intercurrent illness are at risk of worsening hyperglycaemia.

column35: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide information appropriate to their level of understanding about the nature of depression and the range of treatments available
column36: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that comprehensive written information is available in the appropriate language and in audio format if possible
column37: Inform people with depression about self-help groups, support groups and other local and national resources.
column38: Make all efforts necessary to ensure that a person with depression can give meaningful and informed consent before treatment starts.
column39: Ensure that consent to treatment is based on the provision of clear information (which should also be available in written form) about the intervention, covering: what it comprises
column40: Ensure that consent to treatment is based on the provision of clear information (which should also be available in written form) about the intervention, covering: what is expected of the person while having it
column41: Ensure that consent to treatment is based on the provision of clear information (which should also be available in written form) about the intervention, covering: likely outcomes (including any side effects).
column42: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: discuss the presenting problem(s) and any concerns that the person may have about them
column43: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: provide information about the nature and course of depression
column44: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: arrange a further assessment, normally within 2 weeks
column45: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column46: When an antidepressant is to be prescribed, it should normally be an SSRI in a generic form because SSRIs are equally effective as other antidepressants and have a favourable risk–benefit ratio.

column9: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column10: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column11: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column12: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be based on a structured model such as 'Coping with Depression'
column13: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be delivered by two trained and competent practitioners
column14: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: consist of 10 to 12 meetings of eight to ten participants
column15: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.
column16: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column17: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column18: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.

column5: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column6: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column7: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column8: When an antidepressant is to be prescribed, it should normally be an SSRI in a generic form because SSRIs are equally effective as other antidepressants and have a favourable risk–benefit ratio.
column9: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: prescribe at an age-appropriate dose taking into account the effect of general physical health and concomitant medication on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics
column10: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: carefully monitor for side effects.
column11: Do not switch to, or start, dosulepin because evidence supporting its tolerability relative to other antidepressants is outweighed by the increased cardiac risk and toxicity in overdose.

column5: Treatment with either 3 non-insulin blood glucose lowering therapies incombination (triple therapy) or any treatment combination containing insulin 1.1 Individualised care 1.1.1 Adopt an individualised approach to diabetes care that is tailored to the needs and circumstances of adults with type 2 diabetes, taking into account their personal preferences, comorbidities, risks from polypharmacy, and their ability to benefit from long-term interventions because of reduced life expectancy..

column25: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column26: For people with moderate or severe depression, provide a combination of antidepressant medication and a high-intensity psychological intervention (CBT or IPT).
column27: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the duration of the episode of depression and the trajectory of symptoms
column28: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the previous course of depression and response to treatment
column29: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the likelihood of adherence to treatment and any potential adverse effects
column30: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the person's treatment preference and priorities.
column31: Medication management as a separate intervention for people with depression should not be provided routinely by services. It is likely to be effective only when provided as part of a more complex intervention.
column32: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: check adherence to, and side effects from, initial treatment
column33: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: increase the frequency of appointments using outcome monitoring with a validated outcome measure
column34: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: be aware that using a single antidepressant rather than combination medication or augmentation (see recommendations 1.8.1.5 to 1.8.1.9) is usually associated with a lower side-effect burden
column35: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider reintroducing previous treatments that have been inadequately delivered or adhered to, including increasing the dose
column36: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider switching to an alternative antidepressant.

column5: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.

column5: When an antidepressant is to be prescribed, it should normally be an SSRI in a generic form because SSRIs are equally effective as other antidepressants and have a favourable risk–benefit ratio.
column6: Also take the following into account: SSRIs are associated with an increased risk of bleeding, especially in older people or in people taking other drugs that have the potential to damage the gastrointestinal mucosa or interfere with clotting.
column7: Also take the following into account Fluoxetine, fluvoxamine and paroxetine are associated with a higher propensity for drug interactions than other SSRIs
column8: Also take the following into account Paroxetine is associated with a higher incidence of discontinuation symptoms than other SSRIs.

column8: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.

column12: Check forpossible adverse effects of antihypertensive drug treatment – including the risks from unnecessarily low blood pressure. 1.5 Antiplatelet therapy 1.5.1 Do not offer antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) for adults with type 2 diabetes without cardiovascular disease. 1.5.2 For guidance on the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in adults with type 2 diabetes, see the NICE guidelines on cardiovascular disease and myocardial infarction. 1.6 Blood glucose management.

column14: Rescue therapy at any phase of treatment1.6.18 If an adult with type 2 diabetes is symptomatically hyperglycaemic, consider insulin (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34) or a sulfonylurea, and review treatment when blood glucose control has been achieved..
column15: Algorithm for blood glucose lowering therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes.
column16: First intensification of drug treatment1.6.25 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if initial drug treatment with metformin has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: metformin and a DPP-4 inhibitor or metformin and pioglitazone or metformin and a sulfonylurea. 1.6.26 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated and initial drug treatment has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: a DPP-4 inhibitor and pioglitazone or a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea..
column17: Treatment with combinations of medicines including sodium–glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2)inhibitors , may be appropriate for some people with type 2 diabetes; see the NICE guidance on canagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes, dapagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes and empagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes..
column18: Second intensification of drug treatment1.6.27 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if dual therapy with metformin and another oral drug (see recommendation 1.6.25) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider either: triple therapy with: metformin, a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or metformin, pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea or starting insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34). 1.6.28 If triple therapy with metformin and 2 other oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.27) is not effective, not tolerated or contraindicated, consider combination therapy with metformin, a sulfonylurea and a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) mimetic for adults with type 2 diabetes who: have a BMI of 35 kg m2 or higher (adjust accordingly for people from black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups) and specific psychological or other medical problems associated with obesity or have a BMI lower than 35 kg m2and: for whom insulin therapy would have significant occupational implications or weight loss would benefit other significant obesity-related comorbidities. 1.6.29 Only continue GLP-1 mimetic therapy if the person with type 2 diabetes has had a beneficial metabolic response (a reduction of at least 11 mmol mol 1.0percent in.
column19: HbA1c and a weight loss of at least 3percent of initial body weight in 6 months).1.6.30 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, and if dual therapy with 2 oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.26) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34)..
column20: Treatment with combinations of medicines including SGLT-2 inhibitors , may be appropriate forsome people with type 2 diabetes; see the NICE guidance on canagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes, dapagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes, dapagliflozin in triple therapy for treating type 2 diabetes and empagliflozin in combination therapy for treating type 2 diabetes..
column21: Insulin-based treatments1.6.32 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, use a structured programme employing active insulin dose titration that encompasses: injection technique, including rotating injection sites and avoiding repeated injections at the same point within sites continuing telephone support self-monitoring dose titration to target levels dietary understanding.
column22: DVLA guidance (At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive)management of hypoglycaemia management of acute changes in plasma glucose control support from an appropriately trained and experienced healthcare professional. 1.6.33 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, continue to offer metformin for people without contraindications or intolerance.

column25: Gastroparesis1.7.1 Think about a diagnosis of gastroparesis in adults with type 2 diabetes with erratic blood glucose control or unexplained gastric bloating or vomiting, taking into account possible alternative diagnoses 2009, amended 2015 1.7.2 For adults with type 2 diabetes who have vomiting caused by gastroparesis, explain that: there is not strong evidence that any available antiemetic therapy is effective some people have had benefit with domperidone , erythromycin or metoclopramide . the strongest evidence for effectiveness is for domperidone , but prescribers must.

column28: Treatment with either 3 non-insulin blood glucose lowering therapies incombination (triple therapy) or any treatment combination containing insulin 1.1 Individualised care 1.1.1 Adopt an individualised approach to diabetes care that is tailored to the needs and circumstances of adults with type 2 diabetes, taking into account their personal preferences, comorbidities, risks from polypharmacy, and their ability to benefit from long-term interventions because of reduced life expectancy..
column29: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
column30: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column31: Add the other drug (that is, thecalcium-channel blocker or diuretic) if the target is not reached with dual therapy 2009, amended 2015.
column32: Page 16of 44 1.4.13 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with triple therapy, add an alpha-blocker, a beta-blocker or a potassium-sparing diuretic (the last with caution if the person is already taking an ACE inhibitor or an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist). 1.4.14 Monitor the blood pressure of a person who has attained and consistently remained at his or her blood pressure target every 4–6 months.
column33: Check forpossible adverse effects of antihypertensive drug treatment – including the risks from unnecessarily low blood pressure. 1.5 Antiplatelet therapy 1.5.1 Do not offer antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) for adults with type 2 diabetes without cardiovascular disease. 1.5.2 For guidance on the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in adults with type 2 diabetes, see the NICE guidelines on cardiovascular disease and myocardial infarction. 1.6 Blood glucose management.

column47: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column48: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column49: Advise people with winter depression that follows a seasonal pattern and who wish to try light therapy in preference to antidepressant or psychological treatment that the evidence for the efficacy of light therapy is uncertain.

column5: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be based on a structured model such as 'Coping with Depression'
column6: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be delivered by two trained and competent practitioners
column7: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: consist of 10 to 12 meetings of eight to ten participants
column8: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.

column8: Reassess the person's needs and circumstances at each review and think aboutwhether to stop any medicines that are not effective. 1.1.2 Take into account any disabilities, including visual impairment, when planning and delivering care for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.2 Patient education 1.2.1 Offer structured education to adults with type 2 diabetes and or their family members or carers (as appropriate) at and around the time of diagnosis, with.
column9: Explain to people and their carers thatstructured education is an integral part of diabetes care. 1.2.2 Ensure that any structured education programme for adults with type 2 diabetes includes the following components:.
column10: It has specific aims and learning objectives, and supports the person and their familymembers and carers in developing attitudes, beliefs, knowledge and skills to self-manage diabetes..
column11: Provide analternative of equal standard for a person unable or unwilling to participate in group education. 1.2.5 Ensure that the patient-education programmes available meet the cultural, linguistic, cognitive and literacy needs within the local area. 1.2.6 Ensure that all members of the diabetes healthcare team are familiar with the patient-education programmes available locally, that these programmes are integrated with the rest of the care pathway, and that adults with type 2 diabetes and their family members or carers (as appropriate) have the opportunity to contribute to the design and provision of local programmes..
column12: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column13: Reducing the risk of hypoglycaemia should be a particular aim for aperson using insulin or an insulin secretagogue. 1.3.7 Advise adults with type 2 diabetes that limited substitution of sucrose-containing foods for other carbohydrate in the meal plan is allowable, but that they should take care to avoid excess energy intake. 1.3.8 Discourage the use of foods marketed specifically for people with diabetes..
column14: Page 14of 44 1.3.9 When adults with type 2 diabetes are admitted to hospital as inpatients or to any other care setting, implement a meal planning system that provides consistency in the carbohydrate content of meals and snacks. 1.3.10 For recommendations on lifestyle advice, see the NICE guidelines on: preventing excess weight gain, weight management, obesity, physical activity, smoking: brief interventions and referrals, stop smoking services, smoking: harm reduction, and smoking: acute, maternity and mental health services. 1.3.11 For recommendations on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes, see the section on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes in the NICE guideline on obesity. 1.4 Blood pressure management 1.4.1 Measure blood pressure at least annually in an adult with type 2 diabetes without previously diagnosed hypertension or renal disease.

column19: Page 26of 44 who need help from a carer or healthcare professional to administer insulin injections and for whom switching to one of the long-acting insulin analogues would reduce the number of daily injections. 1.6.36 Monitor adults with type 2 diabetes who are on a basal insulin regimen (NPH insulin, insulin detemir or insulin glargine ) for the need for short-acting insulin before meals (or a pre-mixed biphasic insulin preparation). 1.6.37 Monitor adults with type 2 diabetes who are on pre-mixed (biphasic) insulin for the need for a further injection of short-acting insulin before meals or for a change to a basal bolus regimen with NPH insulin or insulin detemir or insulin glargine , if blood glucose control remains inadequate..

column35: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: build a trusting relationship and work in an open, engaging and non-judgemental manner.
column36: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: explore treatment options in an atmosphere of hope and optimism, explaining the different courses of depression and that recovery is possible.
column37: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: be aware that stigma and discrimination can be associated with a diagnosis of depression
column38: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that discussions take place in settings in which confidentiality, privacy and dignity are respected.
column39: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide information appropriate to their level of understanding about the nature of depression and the range of treatments available
column40: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: avoid clinical language without adequate explanation
column41: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that comprehensive written information is available in the appropriate language and in audio format if possible
column42: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide and work proficiently with independent interpreters (that is, someone who is not known to the person with depression) if needed.
column43: Record the decisions and statements and include copies in the person's care plan in primary and secondary care.
column44: Give copies to the person and to their family or carer, if the person agrees.
column45: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: carefully monitor for side effects.
column46: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: referring to specialist mental health services for a programme of coordinated multiprofessional care
column47: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: providing collaborative care if the depression is in the context of a chronic physical health problem with associated functional impairment
column48: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): select medications that are known to be safe when used together
column49: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): be aware of the increased side-effect burden this usually causes
column50: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): discuss the rationale for any combination with the person with depression, follow GMC guidance if off-label medication is prescribed, and monitor carefully for adverse effects
column51: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): be familiar with primary evidence and consider obtaining a second opinion when using unusual combinations, the evidence for the efficacy of a chosen strategy is limited or the risk–benefit ratio is unclear
column52: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): document the rationale for the chosen combination.

column16: Encourage them to achieve the target and maintain it unless anyresulting adverse effects (including hypoglycaemia), or their efforts to achieve their target, impair their quality of life. 1.6.6 Offer lifestyle advice and drug treatment to support adults with type 2 diabetes to achieve and maintain their HbA1c target (see section 1.3).
column17: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column18: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).

column23: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column24: Prescribe metformin with caution for those at risk of a sudden deterioration in kidneyfunction and those at risk of eGFR falling below 45 ml minute 1.73m2. 1.6.23 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, consider initial drug treatment with: a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor or pioglitazone or a sulfonylurea. 1.6.24 In adults with type 2 diabetes, do not offer or continue pioglitazone if they have any of the following: heart failure or history of heart failure.
column25: First intensification of drug treatment1.6.25 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if initial drug treatment with metformin has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: metformin and a DPP-4 inhibitor or metformin and pioglitazone or metformin and a sulfonylurea. 1.6.26 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated and initial drug treatment has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: a DPP-4 inhibitor and pioglitazone or a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea..
column26: Second intensification of drug treatment1.6.27 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if dual therapy with metformin and another oral drug (see recommendation 1.6.25) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider either: triple therapy with: metformin, a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or metformin, pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea or starting insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34). 1.6.28 If triple therapy with metformin and 2 other oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.27) is not effective, not tolerated or contraindicated, consider combination therapy with metformin, a sulfonylurea and a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) mimetic for adults with type 2 diabetes who: have a BMI of 35 kg m2 or higher (adjust accordingly for people from black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups) and specific psychological or other medical problems associated with obesity or have a BMI lower than 35 kg m2and: for whom insulin therapy would have significant occupational implications or weight loss would benefit other significant obesity-related comorbidities. 1.6.29 Only continue GLP-1 mimetic therapy if the person with type 2 diabetes has had a beneficial metabolic response (a reduction of at least 11 mmol mol 1.0percent in.
column27: HbA1c and a weight loss of at least 3percent of initial body weight in 6 months).1.6.30 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, and if dual therapy with 2 oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.26) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34)..
column28: Consider, as an alternative to NPH insulin, using insulin detemir or insulin glargine if:the person needs assistance from a carer or healthcare professional to inject insulin, and use of insulin detemir or insulin glargine would reduce the frequency of injections from twice to once daily or the person's lifestyle is restricted by recurrent symptomatic hypoglycaemic episodes or the person would otherwise need twice-daily NPH insulin injections in combination with oral glucose-lowering drugs..
column29: Autonomic neuropathy1.7.6 Think about the possibility of contributory sympathetic nervous system damage for adults with type 2 diabetes who lose the warning signs of hypoglycaemia. 2009, amended 2015 1.7.7 Think about the possibility of autonomic neuropathy affecting the gut in adults with type 2 diabetes who have unexplained diarrhoea that happens particularly at night 2009, amended 2015 1.7.8 When using tricyclic drugs and antihypertensive drug treatments in adults with type 2 diabetes who have autonomic neuropathy, be aware of the increased likelihood of side effects such as orthostatic hypotension. 1.7.9 Investigate the possibility of autonomic neuropathy affecting the bladder in adults with type 2 diabetes who have unexplained bladder-emptying problems..
column30: When prescribing pioglitazone, exercise particular caution if the person is at high risk of theadverse effects of the drug.
column34: Offer and reinforcepreventive lifestyle advice. 1.4.2 For an adult with type 2 diabetes on antihypertensive drug treatment when diabetes is diagnosed, review blood pressure control and medications used..
column35: Make changes only if there is poor control or if current drug treatment is notappropriate because of microvascular complications or metabolic problems. 1.4.3 Repeat blood pressure measurements within: 1 month if blood pressure is higher than 150 90 mmHg 2 months if blood pressure is higher than 140 80 mmHg 2 months if blood pressure is higher than 130 80 mmHg and there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage..
column36: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
column37: African or Caribbean family origin, or women for whom there is a possibility ofbecoming pregnant. 1.4.8 The first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a person of African or.
column38: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column39: Add the other drug (that is, thecalcium-channel blocker or diuretic) if the target is not reached with dual therapy 2009, amended 2015.
column40: Check forpossible adverse effects of antihypertensive drug treatment – including the risks from unnecessarily low blood pressure. 1.5 Antiplatelet therapy 1.5.1 Do not offer antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) for adults with type 2 diabetes without cardiovascular disease. 1.5.2 For guidance on the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in adults with type 2 diabetes, see the NICE guidelines on cardiovascular disease and myocardial infarction. 1.6 Blood glucose management.
column41: Encourage them to achieve the target and maintain it unless anyresulting adverse effects (including hypoglycaemia), or their efforts to achieve their target, impair their quality of life. 1.6.6 Offer lifestyle advice and drug treatment to support adults with type 2 diabetes to achieve and maintain their HbA1c target (see section 1.3).
column42: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column43: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).

column5: When an antidepressant is to be prescribed, it should normally be an SSRI in a generic form because SSRIs are equally effective as other antidepressants and have a favourable risk–benefit ratio.
column6: Also take the following into account: SSRIs are associated with an increased risk of bleeding, especially in older people or in people taking other drugs that have the potential to damage the gastrointestinal mucosa or interfere with clotting.
column7: Also take the following into account Fluoxetine, fluvoxamine and paroxetine are associated with a higher propensity for drug interactions than other SSRIs
column8: Also take the following into account Paroxetine is associated with a higher incidence of discontinuation symptoms than other SSRIs.
column9: Consider switching to: initially a different SSRI or a better tolerated newer-generation antidepressant subsequently an antidepressant of a different pharmacological class that may be less well tolerated, for example venlafaxine, a TCA or an MAOI.

column5: Treatment with either 3 non-insulin blood glucose lowering therapies incombination (triple therapy) or any treatment combination containing insulin 1.1 Individualised care 1.1.1 Adopt an individualised approach to diabetes care that is tailored to the needs and circumstances of adults with type 2 diabetes, taking into account their personal preferences, comorbidities, risks from polypharmacy, and their ability to benefit from long-term interventions because of reduced life expectancy..

column6: Gastroparesis1.7.1 Think about a diagnosis of gastroparesis in adults with type 2 diabetes with erratic blood glucose control or unexplained gastric bloating or vomiting, taking into account possible alternative diagnoses 2009, amended 2015 1.7.2 For adults with type 2 diabetes who have vomiting caused by gastroparesis, explain that: there is not strong evidence that any available antiemetic therapy is effective some people have had benefit with domperidone , erythromycin or metoclopramide . the strongest evidence for effectiveness is for domperidone , but prescribers must.
column7: Page 27of 44 take into account its safety profile, in particular its cardiac risk and potential interactions with other medicines. 1.7.3 For treating vomiting caused by gastroparesis in adults with type 2 diabetes: consider alternating use of erythomycin and metoclopramide consider domperidone only in exceptional circumstances (if domperidone is the only effective treatment) and in accordance with MHRA guidance. 1.7.4 If gastroparesis is suspected, consider referral to specialist services if: the differential diagnosis is in doubt or persistent or severe vomiting occurs..

column8: Encourage them to achieve the target and maintain it unless anyresulting adverse effects (including hypoglycaemia), or their efforts to achieve their target, impair their quality of life. 1.6.6 Offer lifestyle advice and drug treatment to support adults with type 2 diabetes to achieve and maintain their HbA1c target (see section 1.3).
column9: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column10: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).
column11: Page 24of 44 1.6.31 In adults with type 2 diabetes, only offer a GLP-1 mimetic in combination with insulin with specialist care advice and ongoing support from a consultant-led multidisciplinary team ..
column12: Insulin-based treatments1.6.32 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, use a structured programme employing active insulin dose titration that encompasses: injection technique, including rotating injection sites and avoiding repeated injections at the same point within sites continuing telephone support self-monitoring dose titration to target levels dietary understanding.
column13: DVLA guidance (At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive)management of hypoglycaemia management of acute changes in plasma glucose control support from an appropriately trained and experienced healthcare professional. 1.6.33 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, continue to offer metformin for people without contraindications or intolerance.
column14: Erectile dysfunction1.7.13 Offer men with type 2 diabetes the opportunity to discuss erectile dysfunction as part of their annual review. 1.7.14 Assess, educate and support men with type 2 diabetes who have problematic erectile dysfunction, addressing contributory factors such as cardiovascular disease as well as possible treatment options. 1.7.15 Consider a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor to treat problematic ere
column15: It has specific aims and learning objectives, and supports the person and their familymembers and carers in developing attitudes, beliefs, knowledge and skills to self-manage diabetes..
column16: It has a structured curriculum that is theory-driven, evidence-based andresource-effective, has supporting materials, and is written down..
column17: The outcomes are audited regularly.1.2.3 Ensure the patient-education programme provides the necessary resources to support the educators, and that educators are properly trained and given time to develop and maintain their skills. 1.2.4 Offer group education programmes as the preferred option.

column25: Inform people with depression about self-help groups, support groups and other local and national resources.
column26: Do not routinely vary the treatment strategies for depression described in this guideline either by depression subtype (for example, atypical depression or seasonal depression) or by personal characteristics (for example, sex or ethnicity) as there is no convincing evidence to support such action.
column27: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: befriending as an adjunct to pharmacological or psychological treatments; befriending should be by trained volunteers providing, typically, at least weekly contact for between 2 and 6 months
column28: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.
column29: Do not switch to, or start, dosulepin because evidence supporting its tolerability relative to other antidepressants is outweighed by the increased cardiac risk and toxicity in overdose.

column5: Record the decisions and statements and include copies in the person's care plan in primary and secondary care.
column6: Give copies to the person and to their family or carer, if the person agrees.

column5: Pioglitazone is associated with an increased risk of heart failure,bladder cancer and bone fracture.
column6: Known risk factors for these conditions, including increased age,should be carefully evaluated before treatment: see the manufacturers' summaries of product characteristics for details.
column7: Encouragehigh-fibre, low-glycaemic-index sources of carbohydrate in the diet, such as fruit, vegetables, wholegrains and pulses; include low-fat dairy products and oily fish; and control the intake of foods containing saturated and trans fatty acids. 1.3.4 Integrate dietary advice with a personalised diabetes management plan, including other aspects of lifestyle modification, such as increasing physical activity and losing weight. 1.3.5 For adults with type 2 diabetes who are overweight, set an initial body weight loss target of 5–10percent.
column8: Remember that lesser degrees of weight loss may still beof benefit, and that larger degrees of weight loss in the longer term will have advantageous metabolic impact. 1.3.6 Individualise recommendations for carbohydrate and alcohol intake, and meal patterns.
column9: Page 14of 44 1.3.9 When adults with type 2 diabetes are admitted to hospital as inpatients or to any other care setting, implement a meal planning system that provides consistency in the carbohydrate content of meals and snacks. 1.3.10 For recommendations on lifestyle advice, see the NICE guidelines on: preventing excess weight gain, weight management, obesity, physical activity, smoking: brief interventions and referrals, stop smoking services, smoking: harm reduction, and smoking: acute, maternity and mental health services. 1.3.11 For recommendations on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes, see the section on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes in the NICE guideline on obesity. 1.4 Blood pressure management 1.4.1 Measure blood pressure at least annually in an adult with type 2 diabetes without previously diagnosed hypertension or renal disease.
column10: The assessment shouldinclude: the person's self-monitoring skills the quality and frequency of testing checking that the person knows how to interpret the blood glucose results and what action to take the impact on the person's quality of life the continued benefit to the person the equipment used..

column13: Consider pre-mixed (biphasic) preparations that include short-acting insulinanalogues, rather than pre-mixed (biphasic) preparations that include short-acting human insulin preparations, if: a person prefers injecting insulin immediately before a meal or hypoglycaemia is a problem or blood glucose levels rise markedly after meals. 1.6.35 Consider switching to insulin detemir or insulin glargine from NPH insulin in adults with type 2 diabetes: who do not reach their target HbA1c because of significant hypoglycaemia or who experience significant hypoglycaemia on NPH insulin irrespective of the level of.
column14: HbA1c reached orwho cannot use the device needed to inject NPH insulin but who could administer their own insulin safely and accurately if a switch to one of the long-acting insulin analogues was made or.
column15: Page 26of 44 who need help from a carer or healthcare professional to administer insulin injections and for whom switching to one of the long-acting insulin analogues would reduce the number of daily injections. 1.6.36 Monitor adults with type 2 diabetes who are on a basal insulin regimen (NPH insulin, insulin detemir or insulin glargine ) for the need for short-acting insulin before meals (or a pre-mixed biphasic insulin preparation). 1.6.37 Monitor adults with type 2 diabetes who are on pre-mixed (biphasic) insulin for the need for a further injection of short-acting insulin before meals or for a change to a basal bolus regimen with NPH insulin or insulin detemir or insulin glargine , if blood glucose control remains inadequate..
column16: Page 27of 44 take into account its safety profile, in particular its cardiac risk and potential interactions with other medicines. 1.7.3 For treating vomiting caused by gastroparesis in adults with type 2 diabetes: consider alternating use of erythomycin and metoclopramide consider domperidone only in exceptional circumstances (if domperidone is the only effective treatment) and in accordance with MHRA guidance. 1.7.4 If gastroparesis is suspected, consider referral to specialist services if: the differential diagnosis is in doubt or persistent or severe vomiting occurs..

column31: This is especially important when a person has severe depression or is subject to the Mental Health Act.
column32: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column33: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any history of depression and comorbid mental health or physical disorders
column34: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past history of mood elevation (to determine if the depression may be part of bipolar disorder)
column35: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past experience of, and response to, treatments
column36: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: the quality of interpersonal relationships
column37: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: living conditions and social isolation.
column38: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: discuss the presenting problem(s) and any concerns that the person may have about them
column39: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: provide information about the nature and course of depression
column40: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: arrange a further assessment, normally within 2 weeks
column41: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column42: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column43: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be delivered by two trained and competent practitioners
column44: Also take the following into account Fluoxetine, fluvoxamine and paroxetine are associated with a higher propensity for drug interactions than other SSRIs
column45: Do not routinely vary the treatment strategies for depression described in this guideline either by depression subtype (for example, atypical depression or seasonal depression) or by personal characteristics (for example, sex or ethnicity) as there is no convincing evidence to support such action.
column46: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: befriending as an adjunct to pharmacological or psychological treatments; befriending should be by trained volunteers providing, typically, at least weekly contact for between 2 and 6 months
column47: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.

column7: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: build a trusting relationship and work in an open, engaging and non-judgemental manner.
column8: This is especially important when a person has severe depression or is subject to the Mental Health Act.
column9: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column10: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any history of depression and comorbid mental health or physical disorders
column11: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: referring to specialist mental health services for a programme of coordinated multiprofessional care

column5: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: avoid clinical language without adequate explanation
column6: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that comprehensive written information is available in the appropriate language and in audio format if possible

column5: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column6: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column7: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column8: For people with moderate or severe depression, provide a combination of antidepressant medication and a high-intensity psychological intervention (CBT or IPT).
column9: When an antidepressant is to be prescribed, it should normally be an SSRI in a generic form because SSRIs are equally effective as other antidepressants and have a favourable risk–benefit ratio.
column10: Advise people with winter depression that follows a seasonal pattern and who wish to try light therapy in preference to antidepressant or psychological treatment that the evidence for the efficacy of light therapy is uncertain.
column11: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: prescribe at an age-appropriate dose taking into account the effect of general physical health and concomitant medication on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics
column12: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: carefully monitor for side effects.
column13: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: be aware that using a single antidepressant rather than combination medication or augmentation (see recommendations 1.8.1.5 to 1.8.1.9) is usually associated with a lower side-effect burden
column14: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider switching to an alternative antidepressant.
column15: When switching to another antidepressant, be aware that the evidence for the relative advantage of switching either within or between classes is weak.
column16: Consider switching to: initially a different SSRI or a better tolerated newer-generation antidepressant subsequently an antidepressant of a different pharmacological class that may be less well tolerated, for example venlafaxine, a TCA or an MAOI.
column17: Do not switch to, or start, dosulepin because evidence supporting its tolerability relative to other antidepressants is outweighed by the increased cardiac risk and toxicity in overdose.

column5: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column6: Encouragehigh-fibre, low-glycaemic-index sources of carbohydrate in the diet, such as fruit, vegetables, wholegrains and pulses; include low-fat dairy products and oily fish; and control the intake of foods containing saturated and trans fatty acids. 1.3.4 Integrate dietary advice with a personalised diabetes management plan, including other aspects of lifestyle modification, such as increasing physical activity and losing weight. 1.3.5 For adults with type 2 diabetes who are overweight, set an initial body weight loss target of 5–10percent.
column7: Page 14of 44 1.3.9 When adults with type 2 diabetes are admitted to hospital as inpatients or to any other care setting, implement a meal planning system that provides consistency in the carbohydrate content of meals and snacks. 1.3.10 For recommendations on lifestyle advice, see the NICE guidelines on: preventing excess weight gain, weight management, obesity, physical activity, smoking: brief interventions and referrals, stop smoking services, smoking: harm reduction, and smoking: acute, maternity and mental health services. 1.3.11 For recommendations on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes, see the section on bariatric surgery for people with recent-onset type 2 diabetes in the NICE guideline on obesity. 1.4 Blood pressure management 1.4.1 Measure blood pressure at least annually in an adult with type 2 diabetes without previously diagnosed hypertension or renal disease.
column8: Offer and reinforcepreventive lifestyle advice. 1.4.2 For an adult with type 2 diabetes on antihypertensive drug treatment when diabetes is diagnosed, review blood pressure control and medications used..
column9: Provide lifestyle advice (diet and exercise) at the same time.1.4.4 Provide lifestyle advice (see section 1.3 in this guideline and the lifestyle interventions section in hypertension in adults NICE guideline CG127) if blood.
column10: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.

column23: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).

column10: Check forpossible adverse effects of antihypertensive drug treatment – including the risks from unnecessarily low blood pressure. 1.5 Antiplatelet therapy 1.5.1 Do not offer antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) for adults with type 2 diabetes without cardiovascular disease. 1.5.2 For guidance on the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in adults with type 2 diabetes, see the NICE guidelines on cardiovascular disease and myocardial infarction. 1.6 Blood glucose management.

column12: Self-monitoring of blood glucose1.6.12 Take the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive into account when offering self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.13 Do not routinely offer self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes unless: the person is on insulin or there is evidence of hypoglycaemic episodes or the person is on oral medication that may increase their risk of hypoglycaemia while driving or operating machinery or.
column13: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column14: Prescribe metformin with caution for those at risk of a sudden deterioration in kidneyfunction and those at risk of eGFR falling below 45 ml minute 1.73m2. 1.6.23 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, consider initial drug treatment with: a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor or pioglitazone or a sulfonylurea. 1.6.24 In adults with type 2 diabetes, do not offer or continue pioglitazone if they have any of the following: heart failure or history of heart failure.

column5: When assessing a person with suspected depression, be aware of any learning disabilities or acquired cognitive impairments, and if necessary consider consulting with a relevant specialist when developing treatment plans and strategies.
column6: Do not routinely vary the treatment strategies for depression described in this guideline either by depression subtype (for example, atypical depression or seasonal depression) or by personal characteristics (for example, sex or ethnicity) as there is no convincing evidence to support such action.

column5: Treatment with either 3 non-insulin blood glucose lowering therapies incombination (triple therapy) or any treatment combination containing insulin 1.1 Individualised care 1.1.1 Adopt an individualised approach to diabetes care that is tailored to the needs and circumstances of adults with type 2 diabetes, taking into account their personal preferences, comorbidities, risks from polypharmacy, and their ability to benefit from long-term interventions because of reduced life expectancy..
