column38: Erectile dysfunction1.7.13 Offer men with type 2 diabetes the opportunity to discuss erectile dysfunction as part of their annual review. 1.7.14 Assess, educate and support men with type 2 diabetes who have problematic erectile dysfunction, addressing contributory factors such as cardiovascular disease as well as possible treatment options. 1.7.15 Consider a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor to treat problematic ere
column39: Ensure that consent to treatment is based on the provision of clear information (which should also be available in written form) about the intervention, covering: likely outcomes (including any side effects).
column40: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column41: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any history of depression and comorbid mental health or physical disorders
column42: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past history of mood elevation (to determine if the depression may be part of bipolar disorder)
column43: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past experience of, and response to, treatments
column44: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: the quality of interpersonal relationships
column45: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: living conditions and social isolation.
column46: When assessing a person with suspected depression, be aware of any learning disabilities or acquired cognitive impairments, and if necessary consider consulting with a relevant specialist when developing treatment plans and strategies.
column47: When the person has an anxiety disorder and comorbid depression or depressive symptoms, consult the NICE guideline for the relevant anxiety disorder (see find guidance) and consider treating the anxiety disorder first (since effective treatment of the anxiety disorder will often improve the depression or the depressive symptoms).
column48: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column49: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column50: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column51: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column52: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column53: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column54: In particular, consider prescribing a gastroprotective drug in older people who are taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or aspirin.
column55: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: carefully monitor for side effects.
column56: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: befriending as an adjunct to pharmacological or psychological treatments; befriending should be by trained volunteers providing, typically, at least weekly contact for between 2 and 6 months
column57: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.
column58: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: referring to specialist mental health services for a programme of coordinated multiprofessional care
column59: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: providing collaborative care if the depression is in the context of a chronic physical health problem with associated functional impairment
column60: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: check adherence to, and side effects from, initial treatment
column61: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: be aware that using a single antidepressant rather than combination medication or augmentation (see recommendations 1.8.1.5 to 1.8.1.9) is usually associated with a lower side-effect burden
column62: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider reintroducing previous treatments that have been inadequately delivered or adhered to, including increasing the dose
column63: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider switching to an alternative antidepressant.
column64: Consider switching to: initially a different SSRI or a better tolerated newer-generation antidepressant subsequently an antidepressant of a different pharmacological class that may be less well tolerated, for example venlafaxine, a TCA or an MAOI.
column65: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): be aware of the increased side-effect burden this usually causes
column66: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): be familiar with primary evidence and consider obtaining a second opinion when using unusual combinations, the evidence for the efficacy of a chosen strategy is limited or the risk–benefit ratio is unclear
column67: When prescribing lithium: consider ECG monitoring in people with depression who are at high risk ofcardiovascular disease

column5: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): discuss the rationale for any combination with the person with depression, follow GMC guidance if off-label medication is prescribed, and monitor carefully for adverse effects
column6: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): document the rationale for the chosen combination.

column11: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression

column5: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)guidance (2011) advises that 'prescribers should review the safety and efficacy of pioglitazone in individuals after 3–6 months of treatment to ensure that only patients who are deriving benefit continue to be treated'..
column6: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)guidance (2011) advises that 'prescribers should review the safety and efficacy of pioglitazone in individuals after 3–6 months of treatment to ensure that only patients who are deriving benefit continue to be treated'..
column7: Advise people with winter depression that follows a seasonal pattern and who wish to try light therapy in preference to antidepressant or psychological treatment that the evidence for the efficacy of light therapy is uncertain.
column8: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): be familiar with primary evidence and consider obtaining a second opinion when using unusual combinations, the evidence for the efficacy of a chosen strategy is limited or the risk–benefit ratio is unclear

column5: Explain to people and their carers thatstructured education is an integral part of diabetes care. 1.2.2 Ensure that any structured education programme for adults with type 2 diabetes includes the following components:.

column27: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: build a trusting relationship and work in an open, engaging and non-judgemental manner.
column28: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: explore treatment options in an atmosphere of hope and optimism, explaining the different courses of depression and that recovery is possible.
column29: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: be aware that stigma and discrimination can be associated with a diagnosis of depression
column30: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that discussions take place in settings in which confidentiality, privacy and dignity are respected.
column31: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide information appropriate to their level of understanding about the nature of depression and the range of treatments available
column32: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: avoid clinical language without adequate explanation
column33: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that comprehensive written information is available in the appropriate language and in audio format if possible
column34: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide and work proficiently with independent interpreters (that is, someone who is not known to the person with depression) if needed.
column35: Inform people with depression about self-help groups, support groups and other local and national resources.
column36: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column37: When providing interventions for people with a learning disability or acquired cognitive impairment who have a diagnosis of depression: where possible, provide the same interventions as for other people with depression
column38: When providing interventions for people with a learning disability or acquired cognitive impairment who have a diagnosis of depression: if necessary, adjust the method of delivery or duration of the intervention to take account of the disability or impairment.
column39: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: establishing regular sleep and wake times
column40: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: avoiding excess eating, smoking or drinking alcohol before sleep
column41: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: creating a proper environment for sleep
column42: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: taking regular physical exercise.
column43: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: discuss the presenting problem(s) and any concerns that the person may have about them
column44: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: provide information about the nature and course of depression
column45: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: arrange a further assessment, normally within 2 weeks
column46: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column47: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column48: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column49: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column50: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be based on a structured model such as 'Coping with Depression'
column51: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be delivered by two trained and competent practitioners
column52: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: consist of 10 to 12 meetings of eight to ten participants
column53: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.
column54: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column55: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column56: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column57: For people with moderate or severe depression, provide a combination of antidepressant medication and a high-intensity psychological intervention (CBT or IPT).
column58: Also take the following into account: SSRIs are associated with an increased risk of bleeding, especially in older people or in people taking other drugs that have the potential to damage the gastrointestinal mucosa or interfere with clotting.
column59: In particular, consider prescribing a gastroprotective drug in older people who are taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or aspirin.
column60: Advise people with winter depression that follows a seasonal pattern and who wish to try light therapy in preference to antidepressant or psychological treatment that the evidence for the efficacy of light therapy is uncertain.
column61: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: prescribe at an age-appropriate dose taking into account the effect of general physical health and concomitant medication on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics
column62: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: carefully monitor for side effects.
column63: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: befriending as an adjunct to pharmacological or psychological treatments; befriending should be by trained volunteers providing, typically, at least weekly contact for between 2 and 6 months
column64: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.
column65: Medication management as a separate intervention for people with depression should not be provided routinely by services. It is likely to be effective only when provided as part of a more complex intervention.
column66: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: referring to specialist mental health services for a programme of coordinated multiprofessional care
column67: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: providing collaborative care if the depression is in the context of a chronic physical health problem with associated functional impairment
column68: When prescribing lithium: consider ECG monitoring in people with depression who are at high risk ofcardiovascular disease

column13: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column14: Encouragehigh-fibre, low-glycaemic-index sources of carbohydrate in the diet, such as fruit, vegetables, wholegrains and pulses; include low-fat dairy products and oily fish; and control the intake of foods containing saturated and trans fatty acids. 1.3.4 Integrate dietary advice with a personalised diabetes management plan, including other aspects of lifestyle modification, such as increasing physical activity and losing weight. 1.3.5 For adults with type 2 diabetes who are overweight, set an initial body weight loss target of 5–10percent.

column16: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
column17: African or Caribbean family origin, or women for whom there is a possibility ofbecoming pregnant. 1.4.8 The first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a person of African or.
column18: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column19: Page 16of 44 1.4.13 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with triple therapy, add an alpha-blocker, a beta-blocker or a potassium-sparing diuretic (the last with caution if the person is already taking an ACE inhibitor or an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist). 1.4.14 Monitor the blood pressure of a person who has attained and consistently remained at his or her blood pressure target every 4–6 months.
column20: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column21: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).

column36: It is evidence-based, and suits the needs of the person..
column37: It has specific aims and learning objectives, and supports the person and their familymembers and carers in developing attitudes, beliefs, knowledge and skills to self-manage diabetes..
column38: It is delivered by trained educators who have an understanding of educational theoryappropriate to the age and needs of the person, and who are trained and competent to deliver the principles and content of the programme..
column39: Provide analternative of equal standard for a person unable or unwilling to participate in group education. 1.2.5 Ensure that the patient-education programmes available meet the cultural, linguistic, cognitive and literacy needs within the local area. 1.2.6 Ensure that all members of the diabetes healthcare team are familiar with the patient-education programmes available locally, that these programmes are integrated with the rest of the care pathway, and that adults with type 2 diabetes and their family members or carers (as appropriate) have the opportunity to contribute to the design and provision of local programmes..
column40: Page 13of 44 1.3 Dietary advice and bariatric surgery 1.3.1 Provide individualised and ongoing nutritional advice from a healthcare professional with specific expertise and competencies in nutrition. 1.3.2 Provide dietary advice in a form sensitive to the person's needs, culture and beliefs, being sensitive to their willingness to change and the effects on their quality of life. 1.3.3 Emphasise advice on healthy balanced eating that is applicable to the general population when providing advice to adults with type 2 diabetes.
column41: Encouragehigh-fibre, low-glycaemic-index sources of carbohydrate in the diet, such as fruit, vegetables, wholegrains and pulses; include low-fat dairy products and oily fish; and control the intake of foods containing saturated and trans fatty acids. 1.3.4 Integrate dietary advice with a personalised diabetes management plan, including other aspects of lifestyle modification, such as increasing physical activity and losing weight. 1.3.5 For adults with type 2 diabetes who are overweight, set an initial body weight loss target of 5–10percent.
column42: Reducing the risk of hypoglycaemia should be a particular aim for aperson using insulin or an insulin secretagogue. 1.3.7 Advise adults with type 2 diabetes that limited substitution of sucrose-containing foods for other carbohydrate in the meal plan is allowable, but that they should take care to avoid excess energy intake. 1.3.8 Discourage the use of foods marketed specifically for people with diabetes..
column43: Page 15of 44 pressure is confirmed as being consistently above 140 80 mmHg (or above 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.5 Add medications if lifestyle advice does not reduce blood pressure to below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.6 Monitor blood pressure every 1–2 months, and intensify therapy if the person is already on antihypertensive drug treatment, until the blood pressure is consistently below 140 80 mmHg (below 130 80 mmHg if there is kidney, eye or cerebrovascular damage). 1.4.7 First-line antihypertensive drug treatment should be a once-daily, generic angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.
column44: African or Caribbean family origin, or women for whom there is a possibility ofbecoming pregnant. 1.4.8 The first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a person of African or.
column45: Caribbean family origin should be an ACE inhibitor plus either a diuretic or ageneric calcium-channel blocker. 1.4.9 A calcium-channel blocker should be the first-line antihypertensive drug treatment for a woman for whom, after an informed discussion, it is agreed there is a possibility of her becoming pregnant. 1.4.10 For a person with continuing intolerance to an ACE inhibitor (other than renal deterioration or hyperkalaemia), substitute an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist for the ACE inhibitor. 1.4.11 Do not combine an ACE inhibitor with an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist to treat hypertension. 1.4.12 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with first-line therapy, add a calcium-channel blocker or a diuretic (usually a thiazide or thiazide-related diuretic).
column46: Page 16of 44 1.4.13 If the person's blood pressure is not reduced to the individually agreed target with triple therapy, add an alpha-blocker, a beta-blocker or a potassium-sparing diuretic (the last with caution if the person is already taking an ACE inhibitor or an angiotensin II-receptor antagonist). 1.4.14 Monitor the blood pressure of a person who has attained and consistently remained at his or her blood pressure target every 4–6 months.
column47: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column48: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).
column49: Self-monitoring of blood glucose1.6.12 Take the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive into account when offering self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.13 Do not routinely offer self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes unless: the person is on insulin or there is evidence of hypoglycaemic episodes or the person is on oral medication that may increase their risk of hypoglycaemia while driving or operating machinery or.
column50: Page 19of 44 the person is pregnant, or is planning to become pregnant.
column51: The assessment shouldinclude: the person's self-monitoring skills the quality and frequency of testing checking that the person knows how to interpret the blood glucose results and what action to take the impact on the person's quality of life the continued benefit to the person the equipment used..
column52: Page 20of 44 safety (see Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency MHRA guidance) and tolerability of the drug treatment(s) the person's individual clinical circumstances, for example, comorbidities, risks from polypharmacy the person's individual preferences and needs the licensed indications or combinations available cost (if 2 drugs in the same class are appropriate, choose the option with the lowest acquisition cost)..
column53: First intensification of drug treatment1.6.25 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if initial drug treatment with metformin has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: metformin and a DPP-4 inhibitor or metformin and pioglitazone or metformin and a sulfonylurea. 1.6.26 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated and initial drug treatment has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider dual therapy with: a DPP-4 inhibitor and pioglitazone or a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea..
column54: Second intensification of drug treatment1.6.27 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if dual therapy with metformin and another oral drug (see recommendation 1.6.25) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider either: triple therapy with: metformin, a DPP-4 inhibitor and a sulfonylurea or metformin, pioglitazone and a sulfonylurea or starting insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34). 1.6.28 If triple therapy with metformin and 2 other oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.27) is not effective, not tolerated or contraindicated, consider combination therapy with metformin, a sulfonylurea and a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) mimetic for adults with type 2 diabetes who: have a BMI of 35 kg m2 or higher (adjust accordingly for people from black, Asian and other minority ethnic groups) and specific psychological or other medical problems associated with obesity or have a BMI lower than 35 kg m2and: for whom insulin therapy would have significant occupational implications or weight loss would benefit other significant obesity-related comorbidities. 1.6.29 Only continue GLP-1 mimetic therapy if the person with type 2 diabetes has had a beneficial metabolic response (a reduction of at least 11 mmol mol 1.0percent in.
column55: HbA1c and a weight loss of at least 3percent of initial body weight in 6 months).1.6.30 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated, and if dual therapy with 2 oral drugs (see recommendation 1.6.26) has not continued to control HbA1c to below the person's individually agreed threshold for intensification, consider insulin-based treatment (see recommendations 1.6.32–1.6.34)..

column57: Consider, as an alternative to NPH insulin, using insulin detemir or insulin glargine if:the person needs assistance from a carer or healthcare professional to inject insulin, and use of insulin detemir or insulin glargine would reduce the frequency of injections from twice to once daily or the person's lifestyle is restricted by recurrent symptomatic hypoglycaemic episodes or the person would otherwise need twice-daily NPH insulin injections in combination with oral glucose-lowering drugs..
column58: Consider pre-mixed (biphasic) preparations that include short-acting insulinanalogues, rather than pre-mixed (biphasic) preparations that include short-acting human insulin preparations, if: a person prefers injecting insulin immediately before a meal or hypoglycaemia is a problem or blood glucose levels rise markedly after meals. 1.6.35 Consider switching to insulin detemir or insulin glargine from NPH insulin in adults with type 2 diabetes: who do not reach their target HbA1c because of significant hypoglycaemia or who experience significant hypoglycaemia on NPH insulin irrespective of the level of.
column59: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide and work proficiently with independent interpreters (that is, someone who is not known to the person with depression) if needed.
column60: Make all efforts necessary to ensure that a person with depression can give meaningful and informed consent before treatment starts.
column61: This is especially important when a person has severe depression or is subject to the Mental Health Act.
column62: Ensure that consent to treatment is based on the provision of clear information (which should also be available in written form) about the intervention, covering: what is expected of the person while having it
column63: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column64: Record the decisions and statements and include copies in the person's care plan in primary and secondary care.
column65: Give copies to the person and to their family or carer, if the person agrees.
column66: When assessing a person who may have depression, conduct a comprehensive assessment that does not rely simply on a symptom count.
column67: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any history of depression and comorbid mental health or physical disorders
column68: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past history of mood elevation (to determine if the depression may be part of bipolar disorder)
column69: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past experience of, and response to, treatments
column70: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: the quality of interpersonal relationships
column71: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: living conditions and social isolation.
column72: When assessing a person with suspected depression, be aware of any learning disabilities or acquired cognitive impairments, and if necessary consider consulting with a relevant specialist when developing treatment plans and strategies.
column73: When the person has an anxiety disorder and comorbid depression or depressive symptoms, consult the NICE guideline for the relevant anxiety disorder (see find guidance) and consider treating the anxiety disorder first (since effective treatment of the anxiety disorder will often improve the depression or the depressive symptoms).
column74: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: discuss the presenting problem(s) and any concerns that the person may have about them
column75: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column76: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column77: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column78: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column79: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the person's treatment preference and priorities.
column80: Do not routinely vary the treatment strategies for depression described in this guideline either by depression subtype (for example, atypical depression or seasonal depression) or by personal characteristics (for example, sex or ethnicity) as there is no convincing evidence to support such action.
column81: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.
column82: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: check adherence to, and side effects from, initial treatment
column83: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: increase the frequency of appointments using outcome monitoring with a validated outcome measure
column84: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: be aware that using a single antidepressant rather than combination medication or augmentation (see recommendations 1.8.1.5 to 1.8.1.9) is usually associated with a lower side-effect burden
column85: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider reintroducing previous treatments that have been inadequately delivered or adhered to, including increasing the dose
column86: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider switching to an alternative antidepressant.
column87: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): discuss the rationale for any combination with the person with depression, follow GMC guidance if off-label medication is prescribed, and monitor carefully for adverse effects

column5: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column6: Page 21of 44 1.6.22 In adults with type 2 diabetes, review the dose of metformin if the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is below 45 ml minute 1.73m2:.
column7: Insulin-based treatments1.6.32 When starting insulin therapy in adults with type 2 diabetes, use a structured programme employing active insulin dose titration that encompasses: injection technique, including rotating injection sites and avoiding repeated injections at the same point within sites continuing telephone support self-monitoring dose titration to target levels dietary understanding.

column11: When prescribing antidepressants for older people: prescribe at an age-appropriate dose taking into account the effect of general physical health and concomitant medication on pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics
column12: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider reintroducing previous treatments that have been inadequately delivered or adhered to, including increasing the dose
column13: Do not switch to, or start, dosulepin because evidence supporting its tolerability relative to other antidepressants is outweighed by the increased cardiac risk and toxicity in overdose.
column14: When prescribing lithium:monitor serum lithium levels 1 week after initiation and each dose change until stable, and every 3 months thereafter.

column5: For moreinformation about supporting adherence, see the NICE guideline on medicines adherence. 1.6.7 For adults with type 2 diabetes managed either by lifestyle and diet, or by lifestyle and diet combined with a single drug not associated with hypoglycaemia, support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 48 mmol mol (6.5percent).
column6: For adults on a drug associated with hypoglycaemia, support the personto aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent). 1.6.8 In adults with type 2 diabetes, if HbA1c levels are not adequately controlled by a single drug and rise to 58 mmol mol (7.5percent) or higher: reinforce advice about diet, lifestyle and adherence to drug treatment and support the person to aim for an HbA1c level of 53 mmol mol (7.0percent) and intensify drug treatment. 1.6.9 Consider relaxing the target HbA1c level (see recommendations 1.6.7 and 1.6.8).

column37: When the person has an anxiety disorder and comorbid depression or depressive symptoms, consult the NICE guideline for the relevant anxiety disorder (see find guidance) and consider treating the anxiety disorder first (since effective treatment of the anxiety disorder will often improve the depression or the depressive symptoms).
column38: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): discuss the rationale for any combination with the person with depression, follow GMC guidance if off-label medication is prescribed, and monitor carefully for adverse effects

column5: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column6: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.

column5: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column6: Initial drug treatment1.6.19 Offer standard-release metformin as the initial drug treatment for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.20 Gradually increase the dose of standard-release metformin over several weeks to minimise the risk of gastrointestinal side effects in adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.21 If an adult with type 2 diabetes experiences gastrointestinal side effects with standard-release metformin, consider a trial of modified-release metformin..
column7: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: arrange a further assessment, normally within 2 weeks
column8: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.

column5: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: build a trusting relationship and work in an open, engaging and non-judgemental manner.
column6: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: explore treatment options in an atmosphere of hope and optimism, explaining the different courses of depression and that recovery is possible.
column7: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: be aware that stigma and discrimination can be associated with a diagnosis of depression
column8: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that discussions take place in settings in which confidentiality, privacy and dignity are respected.
column9: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide information appropriate to their level of understanding about the nature of depression and the range of treatments available
column10: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: avoid clinical language without adequate explanation
column11: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: ensure that comprehensive written information is available in the appropriate language and in audio format if possible
column12: When working with people with depression and their families or carers: provide and work proficiently with independent interpreters (that is, someone who is not known to the person with depression) if needed.
column13: Inform people with depression about self-help groups, support groups and other local and national resources.
column14: Make all efforts necessary to ensure that a person with depression can give meaningful and informed consent before treatment starts.
column15: This is especially important when a person has severe depression or is subject to the Mental Health Act.
column16: For people with recurrent severe depression or depression with psychotic symptoms and for those who have been treated under the Mental Health Act, consider developing advance decisions and advance statements collaboratively with the person.
column17: When assessing a person who may have depression, conduct a comprehensive assessment that does not rely simply on a symptom count.
column18: Take into account both the degree of functional impairment and or disability associated with the possible depression and the duration of the episode.
column19: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any history of depression and comorbid mental health or physical disorders
column20: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past history of mood elevation (to determine if the depression may be part of bipolar disorder)
column21: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: any past experience of, and response to, treatments
column22: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: the quality of interpersonal relationships
column23: In addition to assessing symptoms and associated functional impairment, consider how the following factors may have affected the development, course and severity of a person's depression: living conditions and social isolation.
column24: When assessing a person with suspected depression, be aware of any learning disabilities or acquired cognitive impairments, and if necessary consider consulting with a relevant specialist when developing treatment plans and strategies.
column25: When providing interventions for people with a learning disability or acquired cognitive impairment who have a diagnosis of depression: where possible, provide the same interventions as for other people with depression
column26: When providing interventions for people with a learning disability or acquired cognitive impairment who have a diagnosis of depression: if necessary, adjust the method of delivery or duration of the intervention to take account of the disability or impairment.
column27: When depression is accompanied by symptoms of anxiety, the first priority should usually be to treat the depression.
column28: When the person has an anxiety disorder and comorbid depression or depressive symptoms, consult the NICE guideline for the relevant anxiety disorder (see find guidance) and consider treating the anxiety disorder first (since effective treatment of the anxiety disorder will often improve the depression or the depressive symptoms).
column29: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: establishing regular sleep and wake times
column30: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: avoiding excess eating, smoking or drinking alcohol before sleep
column31: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: creating a proper environment for sleep
column32: Offer people with depression advice on sleep hygiene if needed, including: taking regular physical exercise.
column33: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: discuss the presenting problem(s) and any concerns that the person may have about them
column34: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: provide information about the nature and course of depression
column35: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: arrange a further assessment, normally within 2 weeks
column36: For people who, in the judgement of the practitioner, may recover with no formal intervention, or people with mild depression who do not want an intervention, or people with subthreshold depressive symptoms who request an intervention: make contact if the person does not attend follow-up appointments.
column37: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: individual guided self-help based on the principles of cognitive behavioural therapy
column38: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: computerised cognitive behavioural therapy
column39: For people with persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild to moderate depression, consider offering one or more of the following interventions, guided by the person's preference: a structured group physical activity programme.
column40: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be based on a structured model such as 'Coping with Depression'
column41: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: be delivered by two trained and competent practitioners
column42: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: consist of 10 to 12 meetings of eight to ten participants
column43: Group-based CBT for people with persistent subthreshold depressivesymptoms or mild to moderate depression should: normally take place over 12 to 16 weeks, including follow-up.
column44: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: a past history of moderate or severe depression
column45: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with:initial presentation of subthreshold depressive symptoms that have been present for a long period (typically at least 2 years)
column46: Do not use antidepressants routinely to treat persistent subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression because the risk–benefit ratio is poor, but consider them for people with: subthreshold depressive symptoms or mild depression that persist(s) after other interventions.
column47: For people with moderate or severe depression, provide a combination of antidepressant medication and a high-intensity psychological intervention (CBT or IPT).
column48: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the duration of the episode of depression and the trajectory of symptoms
column49: The choice of intervention should be influenced by the previous course of depression and response to treatment
column50: Do not routinely vary the treatment strategies for depression described in this guideline either by depression subtype (for example, atypical depression or seasonal depression) or by personal characteristics (for example, sex or ethnicity) as there is no convincing evidence to support such action.
column51: Advise people with winter depression that follows a seasonal pattern and who wish to try light therapy in preference to antidepressant or psychological treatment that the evidence for the efficacy of light therapy is uncertain.
column52: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: befriending as an adjunct to pharmacological or psychological treatments; befriending should be by trained volunteers providing, typically, at least weekly contact for between 2 and 6 months
column53: For people with long-standing moderate or severe depression who would benefit from additional social or vocational support, consider: a rehabilitation programme if a person's depression has resulted in loss of work or disengagement from other social activities over a longer term.
column54: Medication management as a separate intervention for people with depression should not be provided routinely by services. It is likely to be effective only when provided as part of a more complex intervention.
column55: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: referring to specialist mental health services for a programme of coordinated multiprofessional care
column56: For people with severe depression and those with moderate depression and complex problems, consider: providing collaborative care if the depression is in the context of a chronic physical health problem with associated functional impairment
column57: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: check adherence to, and side effects from, initial treatment
column58: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: increase the frequency of appointments using outcome monitoring with a validated outcome measure
column59: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: be aware that using a single antidepressant rather than combination medication or augmentation (see recommendations 1.8.1.5 to 1.8.1.9) is usually associated with a lower side-effect burden
column60: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider reintroducing previous treatments that have been inadequately delivered or adhered to, including increasing the dose
column61: When reviewing drug treatment for a person with depression whose symptoms have not adequately responded to initial pharmacological interventions: consider switching to an alternative antidepressant.
column62: When using combinations of medications (which should only normally be started in primary care in consultation with a consultant psychiatrist): discuss the rationale for any combination with the person with depression, follow GMC guidance if off-label medication is prescribed, and monitor carefully for adverse effects
column63: When prescribing lithium: consider ECG monitoring in people with depression who are at high risk ofcardiovascular disease

column6: Self-monitoring of blood glucose1.6.12 Take the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) At a glance guide to the current medical standards of fitness to drive into account when offering self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes. 1.6.13 Do not routinely offer self-monitoring of blood glucose levels for adults with type 2 diabetes unless: the person is on insulin or there is evidence of hypoglycaemic episodes or the person is on oral medication that may increase their risk of hypoglycaemia while driving or operating machinery or.
column7: For more information, seethe NICE guideline on diabetes in pregnancy. 1.6.14 Consider short-term self-monitoring of blood glucose levels in adults with type 2 diabetes (and review treatment as necessary): when starting treatment with oral or intravenous corticosteroids or to confirm suspected hypoglycaemia. 1.6.15 Be aware that adults with type 2 diabetes who have acute intercurrent illness are at risk of worsening hyperglycaemia.
column8: Review treatment as necessary.1.6.16 If adults with type 2 diabetes are self-monitoring their blood glucose levels, carry out a structured assessment at least annually.
